description: Adjective and determiner from Middle English scant, from Old Norse skamt, neuter of skammr (“short”), from Proto-Germanic *skammaz (“short”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ḱem- (“mutilated, hornless”). Verb from Middle English scanten, from the adjective. Noun and adverb from Middle English scant, from the adjective.

adjectives.description: Adjective and determiner from Middle English scant, from Old Norse skamt, neuter of skammr (“short”), from Proto-Germanic *skammaz (“short”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ḱem- (“mutilated, hornless”). Verb from Middle English scanten, from the adjective. Noun and adverb from Middle English scant, from the adjective.

entries.meaning: Not full, large, or plentiful; scarcely sufficient; scanty; meager.
examples: a scant allowance of provisions or water; a scant pattern of cloth for a garment

entries.meaning: (uncommon or old-fashioned) With difficulty; scarcely; hardly.

examples: A blonde appeared from the officers' room, wearing a scant of material that passed for issued undergarments.

As soon as the corpse was placed on the pile, and some prayers muttered by the attendant Bramin, fire was set to it at one of the corners, and the wood being dry, and in great quantity, it soon blazed up and consumed the body to ashes, without any noisome smell, such as however does not unfrequently happen if there is a scant of wood, or rain intervenes to damp it.

entries.meaning: (masonry) A block of stone sawn on two sides down to the bed level.
(wood) A slightly thinner measurement of a standard wood size.

verbs.description: scant (third-person singular simple present scants, present participle scanting, simple past and past participle scanted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To limit in amount or share; to stint.
examples: to scant someone in provisions; to scant ourselves in the use of necessaries

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To fail, or become less; to scantle.
